title: WNBA Star Paige Bueckers Makes History With Recent Honor
description: Dallas Wings' Paige Bueckers landed among a historic list of players after achieving her latest honor.
content:
Based on facts, either observed and verified firsthand by the reporter, or reported and verified from knowledgeable sources.

Dallas Wings star Paige Buecker continues to receive impressive recognition for her performance as a WNBA rookie.

On Wednesday, the former No. 1 pick received her third WNBA Rookie of the Month Award, as she recently claimed the honor for August.

For the month, she averaged 20.3 points, five assists, and 3.7 rebounds a game while shooting 49.7 percent from the field.

In addition, she set a record for most points scored in a game by a rookie, as she went off for 44 against the Los Angeles Sparks last month.

The former University of Connecticut star is averaging 18.9 points, 5.3 assists, and 3.8 rebounds per game in her first season in the WNBA.

With her third WNBA Rookie of the Month Award, she becomes the 10th player in the league's history to have done so. The Washington Mystics' Kiki Iriafen claimed WNBA Rookie of the Month in May 2025, with Paige claiming three-straight.

Based on her stats and monthly award wins, she seems to be the frontrunner for WNBA Rookie of the Year, following in the footsteps of last year's top pick, Caitlin Clark.

Per Basketball Reference, the Indiana Fever star won the Rookie of the Month award four times in 2024, while the Chicago Sky's Angel Reese won it once.

Paige would become only the second Dallas Wings player to claim Rookie of the Year in the league's history, joining 2017 winner Allisha Gray.

Before her rookie season ends, Paige could make additional history. The WNBA reported that she's just eight points away from surpassing Arike Ogunbowale's record for total points by a rookie player.

As of this writing, the Wings have the WNBA's worst record overall at 9-32. Their three remaining games are against Golden State, Los Angeles, and Phoenix.

While Dallas won't participate in the upcoming playoffs, the team seems on the verge of returning to the postseason behind Paige's contributions.

Along with that, their record qualifies them to possibly receive one of the top three picks in the next WNBA Draft.

That could result in the Wings drafting Paige's girlfriend and former UConn teammate, Azzi Fudd, to pair them up in Dallas, depending on how Fudd plays this season in college.

Read more: WNBA Star Cameron Brink Reacts to Fan Criticism After Sparks Return

For more on the WNBA, head to Newsweek Sports.
summary: Dallas Wings player Paige Buecker has made history as a WNBA rookie, earning her third WNBA Rookie of the Month award. This accolade comes after she set a record for most points scored in a game by a rookie by scoring 44 against the Los Angeles Sparks. Bueckers is currently averaging 18.9 points, 5.3 assists, and 3.8 rebounds per game in her first season in the WNBA. She is also eight points away from surpassing Arike Ogunbowale's record for total points by a player.
shortSummary: Dallas Wings star Paige Buecker made history by winning her third WNBA Rookie of the Month award, setting a record for most points scored in a game, and is poised to win Rookie Of the Year.

scraped_sources.text:
🎙️ Voice is AI-generated. Inconsistencies may occur.
Indiana Fever superstar Caitlin Clark has been sidelined from playing for her team for an extended time since suffering a groin injury in July.
As the Fever contend for a playoff spot, fans wonder if and when she'll step onto the court to aid them in their quest for the postseason.
On Tuesday, a significant update arrived that could shed light on her return to the hardwood for a WNBA game.
Read more: Fever Star Lexie Hull Shares Black Eyes Update After Collision in WNBA Game
The Fever are scheduled to play the Phoenix Mercury in their next matchup, and are looking to bounce back from a recent loss.
So will Clark lace up her sneakers and help lead the charge against the Mercury, or is she still unable to play?
On Tuesday, The Indy Star's Chloe Peterson shared an encouraging video featuring Clark on the Mercury's court for practice in Phoenix.
According to Peterson, Clark was "running with the Fever backups in their full court 5-on-0" drills.
The video clip features the group simulating a rebound and running to the other side of the court to set up their offense. Clark connects on a three-point shot from the side of the circle.
As they run back to the opposite side, Clark again sets up outside the three-point arc, but instead of shooting, throws a crisp pass to a teammate for a shot attempt.
Clark suffered her groin injury back on July 15 in the Fever's game against the Sun. That caused her to miss the WNBA All-Star Game, despite being named to the team and getting to choose other players for her lineup.
As of July 24, the Fever reported they had not discovered any "additional injuries or damage" related to Clark's injury.
On August 20, ESPN reported that the WNBA superstar suffered another minor injury while working out.
Despite Clark practicing, she is listed as out for tonight's game in Phoenix. ESPN estimates she could return on September 7 for the team's away game against the Washington Mystics.
As of this report, the Fever (21-19) have only four regular-season games, including that Mystics game and Tuesday night's game in Phoenix.
Indiana is currently seventh in the WNBA Standings. Eight teams qualify for the postseason, with four already qualified.
The Fever are contending for one of the final four spots with the New York Liberty, Golden State Valkyries, Seattle Storm, and Los Angeles Sparks.
Read more: WNBA Star Cameron Brink Reacts to Fan Criticism After Sparks Return

Bueckers Earns Third Straight WNBA Rookie of the Month Honor
Wed, Sep 3, 2025, 4:51 PM
Dallas Wings guard Paige Bueckers was named the WNBA Rookie of the Month for the third consecutive month. Bueckers becomes the 10th player in WNBA history and first in Wings franchise history to earn the distinction three times. Bueckers led all rookies in scoring and assists in the month of August, punctuated by setting the single-game rookie scoring record.
The 6-0 guard averaged 20.3 points and 5.0 assists over 10 games in August, not only leading all first-year players in scoring but listing fourth among all WNBA players. She shot 49.7 percent from the field and 93.6 percent from the free-throw line while adding 3.7 rebounds and 1.2 steals.
The month was highlighted by Bueckers’ record-setting performance at the Los Angeles Sparks on Aug. 20. Bueckers scored 44 points to break the WNBA single-game rookie scoring record. She did so by shooting a staggering 80.9 percent from the field, becoming the only player in league history to score 40 or more points while shooting at least 80 percent from the field. Forty-four points are also the most scored by any WNBA player in a game since the 2023 season.
Bueckers enters the final stretch of regular-season games sixth all-time in WNBA rookie scoring and is eight points from the Wings rookie record held by Arike Ogunbowale. She has already broken the franchise rookie assists mark and is seventh in WNBA rookie history in the category. Bueckers continues to lead all rookies in scoring (18.9) and assists (5.3) this season, while listing second in steals (1.58). She remains the only player in the WNBA to rank in the top seven among all players in points (fifth), assists (seventh) and steals (sixth) per game this season.

🎙️ Voice is AI-generated. Inconsistencies may occur.
Los Angeles Sparks star Cameron Brink is still trying to adjust to a significant criticism about her game while playing in the WNBA.
The 6-foot-4 Stanford star became the Sparks' No. 2 pick in the 2024 WNBA Draft, with only Caitlin Clark selected ahead of her.
While there were high hopes for her first season, Brink's rookie campaign was cut short last June when she suffered a torn ACL in a game against the Connecticut Sun.
Read more: Fever Star Sophie Cunningham Gets Honest About Rival Napheesa Collier
Upon her return to the Sparks this season, she's attempting to help her squad battle for one of the remaining playoff spots with teams including the Washington Mystics, Golden State Valkyries, and Seattle Storm.
However, Brink will need to address the continuing issue she has playing for the Sparks that fans haven't hesitated to point out.
During a recent video interview, CBS Sports' Isabel Gonzalez spoke with Brink about many topics, including critical remarks that fans continue to make about her game.
Gonzalez pointed out that just a few games into Brink's 2025 WNBA return, fans were mentioning her issue with getting into foul trouble, indicating it was a sign she's back.
"I don't want anyone to get an and one, so I'm gonna use my fouls," Brink said, adding that she's always struggled with that issue.
"I'm an aggressive player. I'm still working on it," she told Gonzalez.
Her team recently suffered a 92-84 home loss to the Phoenix Mercury. Brink came off the bench to play 14 minutes in which she scored four points, grabbed five rebounds, dished out two assists, and blocked a shot.
However, she also racked up four fouls during her time on the hardwood. WNBA players are allowed just five fouls before fouling out of games.
Brink has appeared in just eleven games this season, averaging 5.6 points, 4.3 rebounds, and 1.6 blocks per game. She's averaging 2.6 fouls per game, which is lower than her career average of 3.4 per game.
In fairness, Brink has only 26 games of WNBA experience due to her injury and recovery, cutting her rookie and sophomore seasons short.
As of this writing, the Sparks are 17-19, but have yet to claim a playoff spot. They'll take on the Connecticut Sun, a very beatable team, in a game in Los Angeles on Friday evening.
That is one of eight games left for Brink's team as they continue their push for the playoffs. She'll just need to ensure she remains healthy and abstains from fouling out if she wants to help the Sparks reach the postseason and succeed.

argos_summary: Dallas Wings guard Paige Bueckers has earned her third consecutive WNBA Rookie of the Month award for August, averaging 20.3 points, 5 assists, and 3.7 rebounds while shooting 49.7% from the field. She set a rookie scoring record with 44 points against the Los Angeles Sparks and is now eight points shy of the all‑time rookie scoring record. Bueckers is a frontrunner for Rookie of the Year and could help lift the Wings, who currently sit at a 9‑32 record, toward a better draft position.
